Explanations about Options.-v:
Tells lsusb to be verbose and display detailed information about the devices shown.
 This includes configuration descriptors for the device's current speed. Class
 descriptors will be shown, when available, for USB device classes including hub,
 audio, HID, communications, and chipcard. Can be used with the t option.

Top-3 Similar Questions: au_738641: What's the command for terminal to find the usb information?
au_1194745: How to create my USB bootable GPT partition?
Top-3 Scripts:
au_738641: lsblk | grep <flashdrive>

$ lsblk | grep Passport
└─sdb1   8:17   0   1,8T  0 part /media/jacob/My Passport1
└─sdc1   8:33   0 698,6G  0 part /media/jacob/My Passport

$ lsblk | grep Passport | awk '{ print $1 }'
└─sdb1
└─sdc1

$ lsblk | grep Passport | awk -F'[─ ]' '{ print $2 }'
sdb1
sdc1

$ lsblk -l | grep Passport | awk '{ print $1 }'
sdb1
sdc1

$ lsblk -l | awk '/Passport/{ print $1 }'
sdb1
sdc1

au_1194745: $ lsblk -f /dev/sdd
NAME   FSTYPE  LABEL               UUID                                 MOUNTPOINT
sdd    iso9660 Lubuntu 19.04 amd64 2019-04-16-19-13-46-00               
├─sdd1 iso9660 Lubuntu 19.04 amd64 2019-04-16-19-13-46-00               
└─sdd2 vfat    Lubuntu 19.04 amd64 039E-EF17

Explanations about Options.-l:
Produce output in the form of a list. The output does not provide information about
 relationships between devices and since version 2.34 every device is printed only
 once.
Explanations about Options.-f:
Output info about filesystems. This option is equivalent to
 -o NAME,FSTYPE,LABEL,UUID,MOUNTPOINT. The authoritative information about
 filesystems and raids is provided by the blkid(8) command.

ul_11631: sudo addgroup usrp

echo 'ACTION=="add", BUS=="usb", SYSFS{idVendor}=="fffe", SYSFS{idProduct}=="0002", GROUP:="usrp", MODE:="0660"' > tmpfile
sudo chown root.root tmpfile
sudo mv tmpfile /etc/udev/rules.d/10-usrp.rules

Explanations about Options.-a: Add the user to the supplementary group(s). Use only with the -G option.
Explanations about Options.-G:
GROUP1[,GROUP2,...[,GROUPN]]]
 A list of supplementary groups which the user is also a member of. Each group is
 separated from the next by a comma, with no intervening whitespace. The groups are
 subject to the same restrictions as the group given with the -g option.
